title: Will the closing yield for the US 10-Year Treasury reach or exceed 2.25% before 1 July 2022?
preds: Wow, big jump in yields after Fed Chairman Powell's remarks.  Upping accordingly
2.31% as of now. Almost certainly done today.
@mjsmith said it. Powell's comments today sent the rate to 2.282% reaching a new high since May 2019. Closed.
Looks like we are comfortably through now on the back of Powell's comments. Maybe a small chance it bids into close and comes below but at this point seems a close above 2.25% is done.

Reported by Seeking Alpha on March 21st, "The 10-year Treasury yield has risen almost 9 basis points to 2.24%." We have gotten close in the past few weeks, but this signal is TOO close not to account for.  My previous forecast is proving incorrect. What can I say other than "past performance is not a guarantee of future results...." I believe we hit 2.25% on the 10-year yield prior to 1 July.
Updating given the passage of time and current bond market price action.
2.24% now. With the dot plot showing an expected 6-7 rate hikes this year, it seems statistically impossible it will not exceed at some point before July 1st
Leaving my forecast alone for now.  Obviously I think its very likely (ie, 90 to 95% chance) that we will cross the threshold but not sure its in the 95%+ certainty range.
Combination of current proximity to the “trigger line”, volatility in the yield, multi-month remaining time horizon, and lack of any indications that upward trend will stop.

Increasing probability given today's Fed short term increase of 25 bps.  Note, that the yield briefly reached 2.248% earlier today before retreating to 2.162%.  With volatility this large, difficult to see how the threshold won't be breached by July.  https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/bond/TMUBMUSD10Y?countrycode=BX

Adjusting now on the back of the Fed's announcement today and outlook for many more rate hikes. Current 10Y has sold off (rallied for yields) to 2.20% so I see a chance we overshoot the 2.25% threshold here between now and July.
Very likely if it holds above 2%
Large increase over the last several days.  Aggregating crowd and rerun Winter's Method and simple AR models, using geometric mean of odds.  Come up with 80%
Increasing odds here, looks like the effect of inflation weighs more heavily rather than any immediate concerns on credit issues in the system

Almost there, 2.09% as of now (24h high: 2.106%).
https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/US10Y
Adjusting upwards to reflect last weeks material move. I think the FED meeting this week will provide further newsflow to confirm or reverse this trend.
Ukraine instability in much of the world.
Upping my bet given today's breach of 2%.  Still much volatility but am leaning towards the upside if Fed really follows through with 25 basis point hikes.

As of this forecast, the US 10-year yield is sitting at ~2%, levels we have not seen since pre-COVID. But historically quite low, with yields falling to 2% in 2008 and staying in the ~2-4% range until 2020. As a bit of a side note, while I am a little skeptical of the predictive ability of technical analysis, it is worth noting that the 2% yield mark has served as a significant level of support/resistance from 2008 onwards. (Instinctually this also makes some sense as the FEDs stated target for inflation is 2% annually, so an annual yield of 2% nominal should be about break-even on a real basis if the FED meets it's targeted goal when averaged out over the 10 year term. Making it a very important level to consider as a bond purchaser). This should indicate that if this 2% level is able to hold in the near term, it should act as support going forward. Fundamentally, the driving cause behind the bond market being at the historically low levels it is the unprecedented emergency monetary policy action taken by the FED in response to COVID. With inflation running hot and the US(hopefully) at the end of the pandemic phase, it seems almost a given that monetary tightening is set to begin soon. I would expect a 25bp raise at the March meeting with more rate hikes likely coming as the FED begins liftoff off of the emergency lows. I would also expect them to look to start tapering assets purchases with an outside chance they may begin unwinding some of their assets off the FEDs books if they want to get more aggressive with tightening. These action over the coming months should reduce buying pressure, meaning that the path of least resistance for yield is likely higher from here. I am leaving a 10% margin of error, mainly to cover possible cases where the FED is scared off their current tightening trajectory due to concerns over the economic implications of sanctions against Russia or some sort of taper tantrum.

Reiteration. 1.7% backtested successfully.
Question returns to whether 2.0% can be broken and held.
-10 since it looks like it's fallen back a bit.

Ten year is at 1.84. Before July 2022 need a 40 bp move. Assuming 100 bp implied yield vol, the standard deviation for a 4 month period is 100/sqrt(3) = 57 bps. So this would require a 0.7 Z move to be on or above 2.25 July 1 = 25% probability. However the question is if the yield at any point touches 2.25%, so boosting probability somewhat from there.

With recent developments, investors are flocking to safety. Given the effects of the war and sanctions on the global economy and supply shortages, but the Fed still angling for at least 25 bps rate hike in March, I think there are serious concerns about future growth (i.e. lower bond yields).
Revising to reflect the sustained downward trend in the yield that is ongoing. 1 July also keeps getting closer and closer.
Quick revised forecast and aggregation with the crowd moves my estimate down to the 50+ % region.
50 bps in less than 4 months is a decent size move, impact of war is unclear on bonds

The crowd has moved down on this one, and with good reason.  Combined with the aftereffects of two years of fighting a global pandemic, the war in Ukraine could create global stagflation.  I'll reduce the odds of a "YES" answer.
It has fallen to 1.75%. The return of land war to Europe will likely keep these rates lower than they otherwise would be.
Trending down so no needs significant reversal to get to 2.25%. Lots of news to come in the next few weeks so remains very uncertain and difficult to forecast.
Now need a 50 bp increase given recent moves
Fed rate hikes and high inflation prints are already baked into current 1.97% yield. If inflation prints higher than expected, the Fed will lean more hawkish, and long term rates will rally.
Yields are back up to 1.99%.Apparently markets aren`t worried about any credit risks arising out of this event, so raising my estimate for now - will keep a close watch

Decreasing my bet based on the "flight to quality" lowering yields with the Ukrainian invasion.  The question is whether loss of Ukrainian wheat and Russian sanctions/supply disruption inflames inflation forcing the Fed's hand.  Hard to say but am thinking downside effect on yields is currently larger.  Raising rates also raises the US Treasury debt service, and with the public debt at record levels (~ $30T relative to a GDP of ~ $20T or ~150% of GDP) that could be challenging https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States.
+5, not sure what effect the Ukraine invasion and sanctions will have, but my guess is combined with the FED raising rates we could see some volatility that crosses the threshold.
With risks generally rising, government bonds again come into favor if credit risk widens, which I think it will. This offsets the impact of inflation to some extent.
Yield is falling, and the Russian invasion of Ukraine is pushing the yield down further

After aggregating my forecasts with the crowd, and prior I end up with about 62% chance - due to the crowd.  All 3 forecast models I run suggest the chance of the 10 year getting above 2.25% during this time frame is much less.
Likely tapering of bond purchases and persistent economic growth through 2022.
Given recent inflation prints, hawkish Fed commentary, and price action in the bond market, I am increasing this likelihood slightly.
Definitely misjudged the volatility quite a bit.  Upping to 67% after rerunning forecasts, aggregating with crowd, then extremitizing result.
with near 2%, getting closer and marking to market - risk of overshoot rises although near-term dynamics suggest more stable yields

Yields have been rising so I'm increasing by quite a bit up from 40. I think I significantly underestimated the chances that the rate hikes in the coming months result in higher yields and was too focused on the long term trend. But the long term trend is over decades and fluctuations can be pretty large in the short term.
Majority of increases in financial yields will be at the short end of the curve
Good chances to exceed but giving risks of a military conflict flight to safety and risks of deflation could push the yield lower again. Hence about 2/3 chance.
Close. Rates are moving up. Good chance it will happen.

US 10-Year Treasury yield on February 10, 2022 was 2.03%, only 0.22% below 2.25%.   Given the anticipated interest rate hike in March, there is a high probability of exceeding 2.25% before July 1, 2022. I will use current crowd forecast of 57% as my starting base.

Updating in response to the yield briefly exceeding 2% for the first time since 2019 during the past few days–and it’s only mid-February. Extrapolating 3-month and 6-month avg. trends puts the yield dangerously near (or slightly above!) 2.25% by July. Considering the higher likelihood that current trends continue and that some additional fluctuations will occur above and below the longer-term trends, it now seems significantly more likely than not that we will see the 2.25% threshold be exceeded by at least a small amount and for a short time.

Have learned an important piece of information about this challenge: the volatility of the 10 year rate has increased markedly over time - even when logged!  I didn't see this until I plotted out the 1, 2, 3, 4, ... n month log differences in yields.  There is an abrupt change in volatility starting in the 1950s that has increased over time, especially in the last 15 years to the present.  When I first analyzed the data, I included data from 1900 on, which had a modest and relatively constant volatility regime.  That skewed my results and probability estimates much lower.  Lesson - ALWAYS check the plots for changes in character, etc that may not be observed in aggregate distributions.  In addition, @JamesEE makes a very good point that this question is positive if the yield just touches the threshold one time.  Given this, I'm updating my probability today quite a bit.
I would need to simulate the volatility better but it's a good point that it just needs to touch 2.25.

It only has to close at or above 2.25% on one day to meet the criterion.  And, as others have pointed out, 7.5% inflation has the market expecting a half point increase in short-term interest rates in March.  I'll increase the odds to 67%.
We're at 2.031 today (due to the 7.5% CPI print), and the market is forecasting a 100% likelihood of a 50bp in March.
Inflation data today and quicker move to 2% pushes this up.
The rate just touched 2.0%, as the inflation report this morning was higher than expected.

Using monthly 10 year yields since 1900, I used Tom Keelin's 4-factor metalog distribution to model the dispersion over time.  It turns out be a very highly peaked central moment with widely dispersed tails (ie, extremely not-normal) over the short time period posed in the question.  This implies ~7% chance of exceeding the 2.25% boundary.  After averaging with the crowd estimate, I come up with 26% for the chance.  Will adjust as needed as more data becomes available
It's currently approaching 2.0%. There remains a decent possibility that the US is facing recession and inflation could recede,

Revising my base rate:
Since January 1, 2012, the 10 year treasury yield has spent (approximately) 1,411 days of 3,682 total days at or above 2.25%. This is approximately 38% of the total time.  https://www.macrotrends.net/2016/10-year-treasury-bond-rate-yield-chart  The last time the 10-year Treasury yield was above 2.25% was on May 29, 2019. The FFR (interest rate) at that time was 2.50%. CME Fedwatch Tool is now calling a 64.8% probability the interest rate (FFR) will be between .75% - 1% by July 1st, and a 32.5% probability the FFR will be between 1% - 1.25%.  https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html# So, Fed approach to curbing inflation will likely be measured at .25 or .50 point raises during the next 4 meetings prior to July. The low interest rates drive people to seek stable, less risky investments in 10 year treasury bonds. The Fed increases the supply of bonds in the market by selling off its' balance sheet positions (as it said it would), potentially suppressing the bond yields (high supply, low demand / yield).  https://www.usbank.com/investing/financial-perspectives/market-news/interest-rates-affect-bonds.html Bottom line: I think there is more of a probability the yield hits 2.25% prior to July 1st, but not 38% probability. I am calling lower.

I think there is a fair chance of this happening. Not only might the feds raise interest rates, but I also expect anxiety due to inflation to pass as/if the causes of inflation are resolved (in the case of the US, supply chain issues).
Broken the 1.70-1.90% area. There is some price history around 2.0% that is the only, potential, remaining resistance. If 1.90 is backtested before going for 2.0%, I'll adjust upwards.
it will go up , but not exceed 2.25%

The Fed Rate would most likely be within the range of 0.75~1.00% and the 10Y yield would be 100~120bps higher, around 2,20%. So the answer with 80% cernainty is No, the 10Y Treasury will not be or exceed 2,25% before the 1st of July
The 2 year yield is rising but the uplift in the 10 year has stalled and inflationary expectations beyond the next 2-3 years remain moderate.

Inflationary pressures continue from energy, supply chains, stimulus package. Labour shortages will exert upward pressure on wages, Ending quantative easing reduces support for assets such as treasury bonds.
Geeze it's either that or the corporate scumbags will eat us alive with inflation....and besides, I'm going to enjoy all those idiot buy the dip day traders lose it all !!    Fun fun
Now 1.82% and rising by the day
1.95% is going to be the point of no return for the foreseeable future.
Upping forecast using an ensemble of Naive/RW 4cast with Drift, an ARMA(1,1), and ARIMA(1,1,1).  After aggregating with the selected crowd I come up with 24%.

I can't make up my mind if it's 20%, 33%, or 50%. If the pandemic has changed the trend, it's around 50%. If the pandemic is just a blip of a larger decades-long trend down, it's around 20%. 33% or 40% seems like the appropriate middleground.

Assuming 80 bps annual yield volatility, the current needed 35 Bp move is about a 0.6 standard deviation event. That alone would imply about a 26% probability but nudging up due to point in time factors.

I think the question being "reach or exceed 2.25% before" rather than "be over or at 2.25% on" makes a huge difference here. At the moment there is quite a lot of momentum behind the current increase. Further inflation will raise it further, and the Fed is now in a position that multiple rate rises are priced in already (because of public statements to that effect). So lack of action on multiple occasions over the next 6-12 months will actually be more impactful that it would have been had they not indicated a high level of hawkishness.  Basically, I think that interest rates would have to be hiked significantly more than expected for the momentum to swing the other way. This would also have to happen soon, as other commenters have pointed out the rate is rising fast enough to resolve as 'yes' by end of February under current conditions. If it happens later it might drop the rate again, but this question will have already resolved!
Now betting it's slightly more likely than not.  This assumes the pandemic eases, the economy grows, and inflation persists.

If the rates continue upwards at anything near the rate we’ve been seeing over the past month, then we should be over 2.25% well before July. However, the US economy is obviously very complex, so there’s also still plenty of room for unexpected developments (or simple differences between current market expectations and future economic outcomes, inflation, etc.) that could put the brakes on further increases, particularly within the 2%-2.25% window.

The rate is slowly creeping up while inflationary pressure remains and interest rate hike remains likely. 
Economic growth continues to rise however inflation appears to continue to threaten disbursable family wealth which will slow economic growth and subsequently stock market performance.

Base rate: The last time the 10-year Treasury yield was above 2.25% was on May 29, 2019. The FFR (interest rate) at this time was 2.50%.  Data / insight below pulled from https://www.investopedia.com/articles/03/122203.asp.  Between 1977 and 2016 the 10-year and 2-year treasury bond yields were 88% correlated.  General correlations affecting bond yield rates:
Supply: Monetary policy (Federal Funds Rate), increase FFR translates to increase in short-term treasury yields (and long term to lesser extent)
Demand: Inflation (Consumer Price Index), higher inflation translates to higher nominal interest rates The current FFR (interest rate) is 0.25% (effectively zero). The CME FedWatch Tool assesses the following probabilities for Federal Fund Rates at the 15 Jun FED meeting:
0.3%   : 0%-0.25%
10.6% : 0.25%-0.50%
49.5% : 0.50%-0.75%
37.5% : 0.75%-1.0%
2.0%   : 1.0%-1.25%
* Data as of 17 Jan 2022 08:31:26 CT, https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html# Meaning of it all: There is a 50-50 chance that the FFR (interest rate) will be just 0.50-0.75% following the 15 Jun FED meeting. Even if the rate is hiked to the 0.75-1.0% range, I do not see this as enough to achieve 2.25% 10-year Treasury bond yield. Jerome Powell's history as FED chair suggests any increase in the FFR we see will be in 0.25% increments (based on 9 hikes/decrements since his tenure started in 2018). There are 4 FED meeting between now and July 1, 2022.

Even as the Feds stops buying Treasury paper other buyers will emerge putting downward pressure on the yields. “ Strategists expect the yield on the 10-year Treasury note to reach 2% this year for the first time since 2019, but they do not expect the rate to go much higher than that.” https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/04/after-rapid-rate-increase-to-start-2022-investors-see-benchmark-10-year-yield-rising-to-2percent-soon.html
-5 on the recent rise seems to be coming back down a bit.
Slightly lowering my estimate, based on a revised random walk forecast with drift.
“We expect the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield to rise in 2022 and be between 1.5% and 2.0% at the end of the year.” https://russellinvestments.com/us/blog/treasury-yields-rise-2022
Hawking stance on the part of the Fed, coupled with increasing evidence of inflation.
Broken the rate of downtrend. Waiting to see this area hold before increasing my forecast.

Increasing confidence that we will hit 2.25 well before July as we’re on pace to break through 2% by the end of February. Bumping up my forecast to account for more hawkish Fed minutes, persistent inflation and rapid move higher in the 10- year rate, all while Fed remains accommodative. Now looks possible that we get 4 rate hikes this year, a quicker taper and smaller Fed balance sheet.
Its already risen that much since the end of December but that could be tied to announcements that FFR is going to go up. But the two things aren't inherently tied except if folks believe its true.

The FED is tapering buying bonds, which probably means yields will rise some due to lower demand. But the steep recent rise seems more like the market pricing in future rising yields. Why buy bonds now if you know yields will rise when the FED starts unloading it's balance sheet a bit? That's what I think the point being made here is saying: https://twitter.com/cullenroche/status/1480387674976313346?t=zFEbGpZ_qrP7owo4HG0RQg&s=19 So I think it's still less likely to happen, but it could get in that territory and a fluctuation could push it over, so I'm going up 15 for now.

Currently 1.73% (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DGS10)
"When the U.S. government runs a deficit, it borrows money by issuing longer-term Treasury bonds to institutional lenders. The more the government borrows, the more supply of debt it issues. At some point, as the borrowing increases, the U.S. government must increase the interest rate to induce further lending." 
"A stronger U.S. economy tends to make corporate (private) debt more attractive than government debt, decreasing demand for U.S. debt and raising rates."
"On the demand side, inflation expectations are the key factor."
https://www.investopedia.com/articles/03/122203.asp Trading economics pegs it at ~1.95% with a confidence interval that appears to be over 90% below 2.25% "The United States Government Bond 10Y is expected to trade at 1.83 percent by the end of this quarter, according to Trading Economics global macro models and analysts expectations. Looking forward, we estimate it to trade at 2.04 in 12 months time." https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/government-bond-yield "The Fourth-Quarter Market Mavens survey reveals that analysts expect the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield to climb to 2.19 percent from the 1.49 percent seen at the end of the survey period. Every single analyst surveyed by Bankrate expects the 10-year Treasury yield to be higher in a year. Their predictions ranged from 1.75 percent to 2.50 percent, with most projections landing above the 2 percent mark. Experts also discussed whether markets were properly factoring in the risk of inflation, with little consensus about whether rising prices were being adequately accounted for." https://www.bankrate.com/investing/market-mavens-survey-bonds-december-2021/ It looks like there's a chance it could crack 2.25% with volatility but few of the long term forecasts expect it to go that high. SMA is 1.5%, is on an upward trend, and seems to be the current basement. It's broken above bollinger bands for the last week and the last time this happened, this time last year, it climbed over .75% in a 3 month period before retreating (which could put us over 2.25%).  If it was a straight line forecast I'd say there's a 10% chance of it being above 2.25% on July 1... but it's not and I've been burned on these before. Still figuring out how to compensate for that but I'll take a stab in the dark and guess it's 3-4 times more likely with volatility, so I'll split the difference and go 35% (ish). If it shows some strength above 2% I'll likely come up further.

By simple extrapolation, it takes it under 2.25%, effectively resolving this NO. However, it is a close call and the trend is approaching it. On the other hand, the trend has been downwards since the 1980s, which could mean this dips down to around 0.93??? Tough call right now but I think it's still unlikely. Favoring the more long term base rate for now but forecast gives some respect to forecasters who are giving this a more probable weight. For future updates, consider going as low as 5%.

Using Tom Keeling's Metalog analysis and assuming interest rates behave as a random walk, my initial estimate of probability of the 10 YR being > threshold by July appears low.  Will revise my bet as we see how the 10 YR series behaves.
Forecasting a higher probability until the current high upward rate of change slows down again.
It spiked from 1.5% to 1.75% awfully quickly.

"Byron and Joe’s Ten Surprises of 2022 are as follows:
[...]
3. The bond market begins to respond to rising inflation and tapering by the Federal Reserve, and the yield on the 10-year Treasury rises to 2.75%. The Fed completes its tapering and raises rates four times in 2022.
[...]"
https://www.blackstone.com/news/press/byron-wien-and-joe-zidle-announce-the-ten-surprises-of-2022/

As I understand it, major drivers of bond prices include the desire for safe-haven assets, liquidity in the financial system, availability of other sources of return, and expectations about the future. Given the pandemic and geopolitical instability as of late, I expect USTs to continue to be the "cleanest dirty shirt".
Liquidity growth should at least decelerate should the Fed actually taper for real, but I'm skeptical they can actually taper all the way and then also raise rates, without something happening that will cause them to back off. Even if they did raise (overnight rates), we could get a flattening yield curve if investors aren't convinced about long-term growth.
Despite negative real rates, the demand for USTs will likely stay strong given that there aren't many alternatives. Everything is overvalued and speculation into alternative assets is rampant (but also off-limits to many funds).
As far as expectations go, in the next 6 months I am imagining that there will be a greater realization that the inflation problem isn't going away and that the Fed can't do what it said it would do. I'm still on the fence about actual impact on UST 10Y yields. I think inflation will stick around, but that the lack of decent alternatives (defined by valuation, volatility, or other metrics institutional investors might use) to treasuries will provide a great deal of support to bond prices.
interest rates will only be hiked max 0.5% by that date.
Bond market is expecting a Fed reaction to high rate of inflation.  The Fed knows it needs to get control while it can still control the direction.
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/TREAST No evidence yet that the tapering has begun. It’ll be interesting to see what happens when it does.
I think the Fed will raise rates and yields will rise in the first half of 2022.

It would have to...
- break a 15 year downward rate-of-trend
- break the recent resistance in the 1.72-1.91% area
- break the 2% marker which have proved to be an area of resistance for 5 years The question becomes one of the possibility of chaotic and rampant inflation.
Remember this is a "touch option" not at expiry
Down 5, toward the crowd a bit.
Growth will be stronger than expected in 2022, Fed will need to tighten conditions and 10 year will eventually rise  to touch that level.

This question fascinates me. After coming out strong with a forecast that goes against the crowd, I’ve lost a bit of confidence in my original projection. I’m going to lay out my entire thought process for and against a move higher in 10-Yr rates, any comments/corrections/thoughts welcome: Reasons FOR a rate move higher 1)	It’s what the Fed wants. If one of the primary reasons for the Fed’s asset purchases was to drive long-term bond prices higher/yields lower to inject cash into a struggling pandemic economy, the reverse should occur with the winding down of the asset purchases. The Fed will only allow inflation to trend meaningfully above its ~2% target (current running 5-7%) for so long and needs to act. Within the window of this question, I expect the Fed’s asset purchase program to be done and at least 1 Fed Funds rate hike in place. The direction correlation between Fed Funds rates and long-term yields is somewhat weak but the removal of Fed-backed purchases of the 10-yr could present a supply/demand mismatch driving bond prices lower/yields higher. https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2017/october/increases-fed-funds-rate-impact-other-interest-rates 2)	With the uptick in inflation, real bond yields have fallen into negative territory. While this country has experienced periods of high inflation and periods of low bond yields, but it has been rare to find both occurring simultaneously, resulting in sustained negative real interest rates. For those who subscribe to the theory that the older generation is flocking to long-dated Treasuries to protect retirement nest eggs, how long will this cohort stick to an asset class generating -4% real yield? https://wolfstreet.com/2021/08/18/whats-behind-this-messed-up-bond-market/ 3)	If the two points above are incorrect, (i.e. the Fed cannot influence long term yields and investors are fine with negative real interest rates for a sustained period of time) the long-term ramifications are bleak. These two conditions harken back to late 1990’s Japan. The result was a “liquidity trap” which left the central bank ineffective in its efforts to stimulate the economy with monetary policy. It might seem silly to worry about this, as Japan's problem was deflation, not inflation, as we are experiencing now, but that's why they call it the dismal science. I also recognize that I might be making an error of forecasting something I “want” rather than what will actually occur, but none-the-less, I don’t see this as a viable outcome.  https://www.levyinstitute.org/pubs/wp_862.pdf 4)	For the question to resolve as a “Yes” the move in interest rates is would not be abnormally volatile. A “yes” resolution requires the 10-Yr yield to eclipse 2.25% at any point between now and June 2022. You only need to go back to May 2019 to find the rate north of 2.25% and as recently as November of 2018 the 10-Yr was above 3%. An 85-basis point move (which is what would be required to go from current 1.4% to 2.25%) happened between November 2020 and March 2021, so not unprecedented, even in recent history. Reasons AGAINST a rate move higher 1)	It goes against a 40-year trend. Interest rates have been declining in straight line since Regan was president. Calls for meaningfully higher rates have proven incorrect for nearly 4 decades. The “outside case” for this question favors downward pressure on yields. https://www.cbo.gov/system/files/2020-12/56891-real%20-interest-rates.pdf 2)	The multi-decade move lower in rates has not been driven by typical default risk concerns. Despite a lot of hand wringing (e.g. NYC debt clock, perennial debt-ceiling debates & austerity hawks) the US Government’s cost to finance deficits has basically declined every year. I’m not going to wade into the politics or conspiracy theories here, but it’s a fact. For now, the Keynesians have won. 3)	Treasury demand is driven by institutional/sovereign investors who either do not care about yield or are happy with a -3% real yield when their home market debt is yielding even less. Contrary to popular opinion, most of the demand for treasuries is not grandpa’s retirement nest egg, but rather foreign governments, sovereign wealth funds, insurance companies and other institutional investors. They have been, and will continue to, purchase T-Bonds regardless of yield to safely park cash, offset liabilities or pick up yield against the Japanese 10-Yr at 0.05%, German Bund at -0.4% or UK Gilt at 0.78%.   https://www.blackrock.com/us/individual/insights/negative-real-rates 4)	Omicron/COVID. We can debate about the impact that the pandemic is having on the actual economy, but the market has been in a “price for the worst, ask questions later” mode for 2 years. I’m having trouble squaring mid-high single digit inflation with a soft economy (I know, I know, stagflation) But the fact is, the market is very headline skittish and the safety of US issued paper is comforting to many.   5)	Inflation fears are overblown. If I’m wrong with this forecast, I’m going to learn something, and it might be something about inflation. My current belief is that inflation is going to be worse than people fear and sustained for longer than people believe. I acknowledge that there is a transitory element because of pandemic-related supply chain issues. But, these issues (and whatever is driving the “Great Resignation”) is pushing blue-collar wages higher. I expect these to prove very sticky and trickle “up” to supervisors and through the workforce. However, I also acknowledge that un-crimping the supply chain plus slower economic growth could fix the inflation issue faster than the Fed can react.

Slowdown in China, rising COVID, plus fiscal and monetary constraint in USA suggest 2022 will have slower GDP growth, maybe even recession. The central tendency for rates should remain in the 2-3% range, but probability of getting there by July 2022 is slipping.
Many underestimate the rising pace and stickiness of inflation. Next year we are up to a surprise in terms of rates and inflation. The Fed will start moving soon and raising the rates

It's difficult to bet against the 40 year bull market in treasuries, but current circumstances nudge the likelihood above 50/50. With acceleration in inflation recently, risk seems to skew towards more aggressive Fed action or inflation running hot for longer -- either scenario should push yields higher.

Omicron. Looks like it could be big and it could stick around long enough to suppress the economy for most of the timeframe. I did not think Omicron could be so big in my initial forecast.

Added cpi and the federal funds rate to the chart. Doesn't seem to me like they correspond all that closely. Also the trajectory of the treasury rate has been pretty steadily downward over the last several decades. So overall I don't think it's likely to rise that high by July, I think the market isn't expecting high inflation over the next 10 years so I don't think this spike in inflation will cause a sudden spike in treasuries. But I'm leaving plenty of uncertainty, the inflation is pretty unprecedented and a stronger economy could cause this to grow too due to lower demand for safe investments.  https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=JQCB My guess is the long term trend has a lot to do with the aging population. Retirees want safe investments and treasuries serve that purpose, as the population ages these become more desirable, pushing down yields due to high demand. It can still fluctuate in the short term, but I don't think we'll see a drastic change due to this trend.

The Fred will taper before it raises rates. This tapering is tightening by other means, and will likely lead to slower growth. This should reduce supply chain pressures and inflation is likely to come down. Right now, the Fed wants to avoid at all costs raising interest rates, as the collapsing 2-10 spread suggests rising recession risks.

The most likely scenario is a return to pre-COVID rates just below 2%. Inflationary pressures could force additional increases but its unclear rate increases will help given the other economic disruptions that have played into increased inflation and are being seen in other countries. It’s more likely that rates will rise to the 2% neighborhood and hold to let other disruptions play out and subside.

The FED will begin to tighten through gradual suspension of quantitative easing, raising their “dot” forecasts for future rate levels and perhaps even raising short term rates.  The middle part of the yield curve (5-10s) should steepen as the policy shifts.
COVID + Jay Powell will continue to limit the Fed's ability to taper and raise rates despite great expectations to the contrary.

Few factors at play here:
1) When was the last time the US10Y was above 2.25%? Looks like May/June 2019 -- so pre-COVID. And it looks like yields few substantially heading into 2020. So in order for yields to return/exceed that level we'd like the US economy to return to pre-COVID levels, substantial re-rating of inflation expectations, or a material change in the supply/demand dynamic of the bond market.
2) So let's consider how the Fed is looking at the economy / their monetary policy -- Jay Powells "hawkish pivot" certainly increased the likelihood of higher rates/accelerated tapering to combat inflation (https://www.ft.com/content/bbbd46e1-75b3-4882-a2c8-bde7a8df7620).
3) So with a quicker taper (less demand for bonds from the Fed, means bond prices down, yields up).
4) On the jobs front the picture seems mixed (https://www.reuters.com/business/us-job-openings-jump-11-million-october-2021-12-08/) but generally seems like we are trending in the right direction and could approach pre-pandemic levels by the summer
5) Given the above picture, I think there is a likelihood that the US10Y could approach pre-pandemic levels by July 1, but pre-pandemic it appears the yields were <2% -- seemed to trade around 1.90% pretty well.
6) There is also a debt angle at play here -- be it a global "taper tantrum" issue or the levels of domestic debt in the US which has risen substantially (total debt >350%) which may limit the level rates can rise given this debt trap and negative consequences of forced develeraging. Given the above, I think it "felt right" to start at 50/50 (tip of the nose) but having weighed the debt trap angle along with where rates were pre-pandemic (~1.90%) I can't see a strong argument for such a substantial rise above that -- so I'll cut that forecast in half and knock off a couple points. 22% is reasonable here.

The crowd's 60% seems very high to me, so this is my personal opinion based on watching these rates for many years, since I own a Treasury bond fund in my IRA. The 10-year Treasury yield has been stubbornly low for awhile, constantly grinding ever downward for years, and it's not really all that volatile, so it will be interesting to watch this. One thing to keep track of is Federal Reserve purchasing of these bonds:  https://www.newyorkfed.org/markets/domestic-market-operations/monetary-policy-implementation/treasury-securities/treasury-securities-operational-details#current-schedule

Multiple drivers appear to influence 10 yr yields. Stock market performance, monetary policy, GDP growth.  Yields last above 2.25% in May 2019 concluding approximately 6 yrs of average yields in the 2.2-2.4% range. GDP, inflation, unemployment and stock market performance all go through up and down periods through that 6-year period. It is unclear what may have been the driving factor in depressing yields below 2.25% in June 2019. Yields have stayed pretty even through massive swings in unemployment and GDP growth perhaps due to steady monetary policy and relatively straightforward stock market performance. Monetary policy changes will likely change over the next 6 months in response to strength of economy and inflation.   https://www.wsj.com/articles/treasury-yields-slip-after-inflation-data-matches-expectations-11639149666
"Treasury yields often rise and fall with inflation expectations both because faster inflation eats away at the purchasing power of interest payments and because it can lead the Fed to lift short-term interest rates, which play a major role in determining short-term Treasury yields in particular." https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/10/fed-is-expected-to-speed-up-end-of-bond-buying-and-signal-interest-rate-hikes-are-coming.html https://think.ing.com/articles/rates-outlook-if-10-yr-treasury-cant-hit-2-percent-the-fed-will-be-constrained/

Looking at treasury data for the last couple of years it has varied from about 0.5 to about 2.5, it's currently at about 1.5 and has been mostly stable through this year. A 50% increase in 6 months would be pretty drastic, but could happen depending on economic recovery.

The key points which influence the 10 year US yield
1> The real rate of growth - The rate which one would expect to earn if there were no inflation. (In other words if inflation were accounted for). This can be ascertained from the long term expectations of growth or the TIPS (which is an indicator of the inflation adjusted return) 
As of now, the 10 year US TIPS is negative, which means longer term growth prospects are poor. https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/US10YTIP
Which means that the market thinks the current prospects for long term growth are dim.
2> Inflation - The US 10 year yield = The TIPS rate + Expected inflation. This equation gives a rough sense of what the market expects the average inflation to be over the next 10 years. Based on the closing prices of 10th Dec 21, this is approx 2.5% {i.e 1.49% - (-1.009%)}
3>  Credit risk - If credit risk in the economy rises, demand for US government debt will rise leading to a fall in the yields as US government debt is considered the safest of all borrowings.
So to sum up If Inflation rises (ie market thinks average inflation over 10 years is going to be higher than 2.5%). The US 10Y yield will go up.
If long term growth prospects improve then the US 10Y yield will go up and vice versa.
If credit risk in the economy increases the Yield will go down as people will prefer to hold US government securities instead of corporate loans(The TED spread is a decent measure of credit risk )https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/TEDRATE Scenarios favoring a No
1> Omicron disrupts growth momentum, we see a disruption of economic activities
2> A big credit event/default Scenarios favoring a Yes
1> Growth picks up post the govt spending plan.
2> Longer term Inflation expectations are revised higher (somewhat related to point 1) Slightly tilting towards a No at this point, Want to see the aftermath of the Evergrande default, Omicron virus and tapering of monetary stimulus.

In addition to the great points by @erikbays , this question’s outcome should also track closely with how COVID evolves globally in 1H22, and in the USA in particular. I’m hopeful that Omicron will be the last major variant to hit the economy/markets hard (that’s all still primarily just forecasts at this point, but still very likely to have unhelpful/painful impacts…), and so there’s still a good amount of time for things to get worse and then recover, allowing the economy to kick into high gear before July.

This is a great question. Once they have settled the budget in Congress we will start seeing a lot more debt go on to the market. Also the fed and other nations are going to be buying less debt, at least supposedly. Also inflationary pressures should be working to push up interest rates. So all of these things should bring us above 2.25% especially considering it is historically unusual for bond rates to be this low. However, as inflation causes more problems for the stock market, investors will likely pull out of the stock market and go into bonds as a safety (which is ridiculous because bonds have a negative real return). And ultimately the treasury market is not a real market and hasn't been for a long time. In any rational world treasury rates would not have a negative real return for such a long time. Rates are low because the FED keeps them low artificially and they have to keep them low because the United States cannot afford to pay a market rate of interest on the debt. So I think this is really a question about what we think the FED is willing to let rates go to. A very large portion of the national debt is on short-term notes, so really the US government has the equivalent of an adjustable rate mortgage. If treasury rates go up it doesn't take very long for the debt in 3 month, 6 month, 1 year bonds that is being rolled over to go to higher interest rates and the US is quickly paying a higher amount of interest. Also keep in mind that the 10-year treasury is very crucial because it is a benchmark for many financial rates such as the mortgage rate. If the 10-year rate goes up, mortgage rates go up, and there goes your wealth effect that the FED is trying to create. If low rates create wealth then the corollary has to be true that higher rates will eliminate wealth. Not that 2.25 is that high historically, but the market is so addicted to low rates now that I think it's pretty high by today's standards.  Ultimately I'm going to give this a pretty high likelihood because of the chance of it flashing up above 2.25 for a short time.
